comment: Formed with a participialized form of the Perfect, has a weak inferential meaning.
The distribution of allomorphs used to form the General Converb is described in Creissels (2012), also referenced under “Source”.

-no is also the participle/converb suffix, it attaches to aorist to form "reported aorist", another morpheme -lo exists, which is homophonous with the subjunctive and forms reported equivalents of tenses other than the aorist.
Used in negative contexts, similar to the Aorist Reported (aorist + -no).
The copula is optional for indirect evidentiality (Unwitnessed) and obligatory for Perfect.
Converb is equal to Aorist. Copula is sometimes added directly to the bare stem as a suffix.
There are two more allomorphs of the Past Converb, but their form is unreadable in the scan of the book.
Converb is equal to participle. Evidential meaning is described in Desheriev (1963).
Converb is equal to participle.
Zero copula in third person.
Auxiliary is the present progressive of the existential verb ‘be’.
Copula reappears under negation.
Converb is equal to participle.

Labeled прошедшее несовершенное. It is unclear what that means, and no phrasal examples are provided. Update: has perfect and evidential meaning according to Xalidova (2019). Very likely also has resultative meaning.
Also expresses spatial deixis “lower than the speaker”. As a result, it does not combine with first person (see page 169 on Present Definite II).
Interpretation (at least for transitive verbs) depends on case form of the subject. According to Friedman (1984) there is no “pure resultative” in Lak.
Auxiliary ‘be in’.
Is said to originate from converb -Ib + auxiliary tur-ur ‘stands’.
No evidential meaning according to Baskakov (1940), though it seems to appear as a narrative tense in the fairy tales he recorded.
Converb is equal to perfective stem.
Copula reappears in negation. Converb is equal to Past.
Converb is equal to perfective stem and Aorist.
Converb is equal to perfective stem and Aorist.
Copula reappears under negation.
Reconstructed as analytic by Maisak (2018: 158), based on negation. Reconstructed form of the lexical verb is the form in -i, which functions as Aorist, Perfective Participle and Aorist Converb.
There is also a difficult to evaluate General Resultative Tense with a present tense auxiliary and a future-like meaning.
